choices.text: Both light reflex and near reflex intact
Both light reflex and near reflex absent
Light reflex is absent and near reflex is present
Light reflex is present and near reflex is absent

questions.solution:
Ans. C) Light reflex is absent and near reflex is present

 

Option C:

 

  • Parinaud syndrome is dorsal midbrain syndrome.
  • The Pretectal nuclei responsible for the pupillary light reflex lie more dorsally than those controlling the near reflex, making them more susceptible to compressive effects. Therefore, dorsal midbrain lesions typically result in the loss of the pupillary light reflex and, preservation of the near reflex.
  • Features:
    • Straight eyes in the primary position
    • Supranuclear up gaze and downgaze palsy on saccadic movement
    • Large pupils with light–near dissociation
    • Lid retraction (Collier sign)
    • Convergence–retraction nystagmus

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Both light reflex and near reflex intact: In Parinaud’s Syndrome, the patient typically has a problem with vertical gaze, especially upward gaze, due to a lesion in the midbrain and light-near dissociation.

 

Option B. Both light reflex and near reflex absent: This is less characteristic of Parinaud’s Syndrome.

 

Option D. Light reflex is present and near reflex is absent: This is less typical for Parinaud’s Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most characteristic feature of Parinaud’s Syndrome is the light-near dissociation, where the pupillary light reflex is absent but the near reflex is preserved. This is due to the involvement of the pretectal area while sparing the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 807

questions.text: A patient presents with left side Abducens nerve and Facial nerve weakness with right sided hemiplegia.  Which of the following syndromes presents in this manner?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Millard Gubler syndrome

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Weber Syndrome

 

 

Option B: Gradenigo Syndrome

 

 

Option D: Foville Syndrome

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Millard-Gubler syndrome as a brainstem stroke syndrome characterized by ipsilateral facial paralysis and abducens nerve palsy, with contralateral hemiparesis, due to a lesion in the ventral pons.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 803

questions.text: Identify the site of lesion:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MLF

 

Option B:

 

In the picture given, primary gaze and dextroversion appears normal. In levoversion, there is defective adduction of the right eye. This is suggestive of right sided INTERNUCLEAR OPHTHALMOPLEGIA.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. PPRF (Paramedian Pontine Reticular Formation) is involved in initiating horizontal eye movements, but a lesion here would not specifically cause INO.

 

Option C. Both PPRF and MLF: While lesions in these areas affect eye movement, INO is exclusively associated with a lesion in the MLF.

 

Option D. riMLF (rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus) is involved in vertical eye movement, not typically associated with INO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia is specifically associated with a lesion in the MLF, which disrupts the coordination of eye movements.

Top of Form

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 806

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed to have right sided oculomotor nerve palsy with left sided hemiplegia. The syndrome associated with the given scenario is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weber’s syndrome

 

Option B:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: BENEDIKT’S SYNDROME

 

 

Option C: CLAUDE SYNDROME

 

 

Option D: NOTHNAGEL SYNDROME

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Ipsilateral third nerve paresis and contralateral hemiparesis are features of weber’s syndrome.

 

REF: KANSKI 8TH EDITION PAGE 822

questions.text: A middle-aged male presented to the OPD with a head tilt to the left side. On examination, it is observed that he has right hypertropia which increases on levoversion and left head-tilt. Which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left superior rectus

 

Explanation:

 

In this question, the patient presenting with left head tilt is the compensatory head position to avoid diplopia. Analysis of paretic muscle is done in primary position. Student must not get confused between head tilt at presentation and the head tilt in which the hypertropia is more.

 

  • Head tilt is a form of compensatory head posture to avoid diplopia.

  • In case of 4th nerve palsy – head tilt is towards the opposite side.

  • PARK THREE STEP TEST – allows to identify the muscle involved in patients with vertical diplopia.

 

 

The student must not try to learn the outcomes of this table. While analysing any question on Park 3 step test, it is better to draw the following diagram:

 

 

Step 1: which eye is hypertropic: The elevators of the contralateral eye are paretic or depressors of ipsilateral eye are paretic. So in this case, it is right hypertropia. Thus, contralateral LSR or  LIO or ipsilateral RSO or RIR. 

 

Step 2: Which Gaze: Draw a circle around the muscles on that side of the diagram, the gaze in which the hypertropia is more. So in this case, it is more on left gaze, thus, LSR or RSO

 

Step 3: Which head tilt: Draw a diagonal line – upper side of the line starts from the upper corner of the direction of head tilt. So in this case, left head tilt, Thus the correct answer would be LSR. 

 

Interpretation: The muscle which lies in the interjection of all the 3 steps, is the paretic muscle.

 

Other example for practice in which hypertropia is more with right head tilt. The answer changes to Left Inferior Oblique.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the concept behind Park Three step test is crucial. Step-wise approach to such questions are necessary to solve them.

 

REF: KANSKI 8TH EDITION PAGE 826-827

questions.text: In a patient, see-saw nystagmus is noted, that is, one eye rises up and intorts, while the other shifts down and extorts. What cannot be a cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wernicke’s encephalopathy

 

Option A.

 

  • This condition is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency and primarily affects the thalamus and hypothalamus. Instead, horizontal or gaze-evoked nystagmus is more common in Wernicke’s encephalopathy.
  • Downbeat nystagmus (vertical nystagmus with fast phase beating downwards) is noted in Wernicke’s encephalopathy, not see-saw nystagmus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Brainstem Stroke: Lesions in the brainstem can cause see-saw nystagmus, as the brainstem plays a key role in coordinating eye movements.

 

Option C. Parasellar Lesions: Lesions in the parasellar region (near the sella turcica in the skull) can affect structures like the pituitary gland and optic chiasm, and in some cases, can lead to see-saw nystagmus.

 

Option D. Syringobulbia: This is a progressive disorder characterized by the development of a fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) within the brainstem. It can disrupt the coordination of eye movements and cause various types of nystagmus, including see-saw nystagmus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

See-saw nystagmus is most commonly associated with lesions in the diencephalon or midbrain, and is less likely to be caused by Wernicke’s encephalopathy, which typically presents with horizontal nystagmus.

 

REF: KANSKI 8TH EDITION 837

choices.text: Elevation of upper lid on downgaze
Adduction on attempted vertical gaze
Retraction of globe on vertical movements

questions.text: True about aberrant regeneration of third nerve are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retraction of Globe on Vertical Movements

 

Option D:

 

This is not a feature of aberrant regeneration of the third nerve In Duane’s syndrome, there is retraction of the globe and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on adduction due to co-innervation of the lateral and medial rectus muscles.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Elevation of upper lid on downgaze

 

Pseudo-von Graefe lid sign:

 

  • As the eye attempts to move downwards the upper lid retracts 

  • the fibres originally supplying the inferior rectus muscle are now misdirected to supply the levator palpebrae superioris.

 

Option B. Gaze-Evoked Pupillary Dilatation: This is also a sign of aberrant regeneration. Normally, the pupil constricts in response to light and during accommodation, but with aberrant regeneration, movements of the eye can cause abnormal reactions in the pupil

 

Pseudo-Argyll Robertson pupil:

 

  • There is a slow light reflex and a better constriction of the pupil with the near synkinesis.

  • Fibres supplying the sphincter are damaged and fibres to the ciliary muscle for accommodation are misdirected to the pupil.

 

Option C. Adduction on attempted vertical gaze

 

Horizontal gaze lid dyskinesis:

 

  • The upper lid retracts as the eye is adducted and falls as the eye is abducted.

  • medial rectus fibres now supply the levator.

  1. Difficulty in vertical gaze.

  2. Adduction on attempted vertical gaze - superior rectus fibres misdirected to the medial rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retraction of the globe on vertical movements is not a characteristic of aberrant third nerve regeneration, but rather of Duane’s syndrome.

 

REF: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE PAGE 446

questions.text: This patient presented with bilateral ptosis. On application of ice, there was improvement in the ptosis. The likely diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myasthenia gravis

 

Option B:

 

  • Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disease in which antibodies mediate damage and destruction of acetylcholine receptors in striated muscle.
  • The test being done is ICE PACK TEST.
  • Improvement of ptosis on application of ice for 2 minutes is noted in MG as cold inhibits the breakdown of acetylcholine by acetylcholinesterase.
  • It is around 75% sensitive but highly specific.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Myotonic Dystrophy: This is a type of muscular dystrophy, characterized by progressive muscle wasting and weakness. It does not typically respond to the ice pack test.

 

Option C. Progressive External Ophthalmoplegia (PEO): This is a condition characterized by weakness of the eye muscles. While PEO shares some symptoms with myasthenia gravis, such as drooping eyelids and double vision, it does not respond to the ice pack test.

 

Option D. Millard-Gubler Syndrome: This is a rare condition characterized by facial paralysis, abducens nerve paralysis, and contralateral hemiplegia. It is not associated with a positive response to the ice pack test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ice pack test is most commonly used to diagnose myasthenia gravis, particularly when ocular symptoms like ptosis are present. It is not typically used or effective in diagnosing myotonic dystrophy, progressive external ophthalmoplegia, or Millard-Gubler syndrome.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION page 815

questions.text: The cranial nerve with the longest intracranial course is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4

 

Option B:

 

Trochlear nerve is the nerve with the longest intracranial course.

 

Key features of Trochlear Nerve:

 

  • A very long and slender nerve, increasing its vulnerability.
  • The only cranial nerve to emerge from the dorsal aspect of the brain.
  • The only decussated (crossed) cranial nerve besides the optic nerve, innervating the superior oblique muscle contralateral to its nucleus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 3 (Oculomotor Nerve): While the oculomotor nerve has an important and complex role in eye movement, controlling most of the eye's muscles, its intracranial course is not as long as that of the trochlear nerve.

 

Option C. 6 (Abducens Nerve): The abducens nerve has a significant intracranial course, but it is not the longest. It innervates the lateral rectus muscle of the eye.

 

Option D. 2 (Optic Nerve): The optic nerve, which is responsible for vision, has a significant pathway starting from the retina to the optic chiasm and then to the brain. However, its intracranial length is not the longest among the cranial nerves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that the cranial nerve with the longest intracranial course is the trochlear nerve (CN IV).

 

Ref: pg 546/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA
